current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
Celebrating the 20th anniversary of the
		  Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993.

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and
			 Pensions

cosponsor.#tail:
) submitted the following
			 resolution; which was referred to the

text.#text: That the

recognizes and
			 honors the 20th anniversary of the enactment of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Family and Medical Leave
			 Act of 1993
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993

text.#text:
salutes all of
			 the individuals who contributed to the enactment of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: ; and

text.#text:
encourages all
			 individuals in the United States to celebrate the advance of workplace
			 protections and opportunities made possible by the enactment of the

pledges to
			 continue to work on a bipartisan basis to ensure that all individuals in the
			 United States are able to balance work and family responsibilities.

Whereas February 5, 2013, marks the 20th anniversary of
			 the enactment of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , which was signed by President Bill Clinton;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993

text.#text: Whereas the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, employees often did not have access to leave from work, or feared
			 losing their jobs if they took leave, when the employee or an immediate family
			 member faced a serious health condition, or when recovering from giving birth
			 or bonding with a new child;

text.#text: Whereas prior to the passage of the
Whereas prior to the passage of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
worked in a bipartisan manner to craft
			 the

text.#text: Whereas

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
was the
			 culmination of years of hard work and is a lasting legacy for Senators Chris
			 Dodd and Kit Bond and Representatives Pat Schroeder and Marge Roukema, among
			 many others;

text.#text: Whereas the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: are—

text.#text: Whereas the purposes of the

to balance the
			 demands of the workplace with the needs of families;

to promote the
			 stability and economic security of families;

to promote
			 national interests in preserving family integrity;

to entitle
			 employees to take reasonable leave for medical reasons, the birth or adoption
			 of a child, and the care of a child, spouse, or parent with a serious health
			 condition;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
in a manner that accommodates
			 the legitimate interests of employers and minimizes the potential for
			 employment discrimination on the basis of sex; and

text.#text:
to accomplish the
			 purposes described in

to promote the
			 goal of equal employment opportunity for women and men;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
allows an
			 employee to take up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave to bond with a newborn or newly
			 adopted child, to care for a child, spouse, or parent with a serious health
			 condition, and to tend to a serious health condition of the employee;

text.#text: Whereas the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
benefits newborn
			 or newly adopted children by creating strong family bonds, allowing families
			 time to make arrangements for future caregiving, and promoting the
			 establishment of healthy practices such as breastfeeding;

text.#text: Whereas the
Whereas the
Whereas the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
recognized the unique family needs of
			 military families and acted with bipartisan support in enacting the
to meet the needs of military families;

text.#text: Whereas

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
National
			 Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to expand the protections of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2010
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2010

text.#text: Whereas the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
provides up to 26
			 weeks of leave to care for a member of the Armed Forces or recent veteran who
			 was seriously injured or became seriously ill because of active duty in the
			 United States Armed Forces;

text.#text: Whereas the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
helps the United
			 States to fulfill the responsibility to support military families and care for
			 wounded warriors; and

text.#text: Whereas the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has been invoked
			 more than 100,000,000 times, allowing millions of families to attend to both
			 work and family responsibilities: Now, therefore, be it

text.#text: Whereas the
